right room if you're more advanced this might be a little rudimentary for you so i'm going to try
to do my best not to use acronyms or if i do explain what they mean and i'm going to be talking about a
number of things today and i've been in amazon for a few years now when i started we had really two
products our flagship s3 which i'll explain today in ebs and
since then we've launched glacier which i'll explain today we've launched direct connect the aws
storage gateway so we've been innovating really fast so today we're
going to talk about scalable storage and that's our flagship s3 we're going to talk about
inexpensive archival storage and i'll define a little bit what an archive
means uh because it's not for use for anything other than archive we'll talk about persistent direct attach
storage to support ec2 instances we'll talk about our turnkey gateway solution
and then tomorrow we'll be coming up from imemories who's the ceo of imemories and she'll be talking about

like in her future use of aws and she actually launched her business the same year that we launched aws
so in terms of data we're constantly producing more and more data multiple
formats customers want access to their data anywhere anytime on any device
as i watched andy jassy's speech i watched twitter just blow up which is a customer of ours and in terms
of growth we have customers on top of aws from a storage perspective that grow by a petabyte per day
just a single customer it's staggering i never thought when i got into storage 20 years ago i would see this kind of growth but it's
massive many of those are consumer apps right we're all users of the cloud as consumers but the enterprise as you
saw today is also adopting the cloud for obvious reasons you look at oil and gas as an industry
right they've got sensors thank you all the way down to the tip of the drill that are producing
massive amounts of data and this is data that needs to be saved forever right we're seeing adoption in
life sciences we're seeing adoption in the financial sector with companies such as nasdaq who
recently launched fincloud about a year ago which is a financial services focused archive
solution for financial services dealer brokers and it had to be worm compliant and sec
compliant they launched that on top of aws and when they came to us with the idea in may of last year
we want to launch this service and we're not sure how fast our customers will adopt and we want to offer it to more than just folks at
trade on nasdaq we want to offer to the financial community worldwide it's expensive to keep worm compliant data meaning it's immutable it cannot be
changed deleted or modified until the retention period has expired that's typically seven years
so they turned to their internal i.t team and said how much to build it they said well how big is it going to be
well we don't know okay well what's the adoption curve going to look like we don't know okay rough estimate 10 to
20 million about 18 months to put the kit together so this is may of last year
by october we launched fincloud and we helped them ring the closing bell in october which was
fantastic they're now multi-petabyte level and their aws bill to develop the
application was less than a thousand dollars so really compelling what the enterprise
is doing they're innovating now fast as the the startup and what they use is our object store
right and it's called s3 which is simple storage service and it's called simple storage service
because very simple to use you use very simple protocols like puts gets
copies deletes those are transactions on top of s3 and we and that's done via
soap and rest apis and for those of you in the room that are not from the development world and you're from
the data center world you don't use soap and rest apis you're probably more familiar with protocols like iscsi
sifs nfs i'll talk a little bit about how you can use those protocols to interact with s3 just like you interact
with traditional on-prem storage an s3 is durable it's the most durable
storage subsystem on the planet to our knowledge it carries eleven nines of durability what that
means is if you had statistically 10 000 objects in s3 you can expect to lose one every 10
million years so very very durable storage customers using s3 do not keep multiple copies elsewhere
because we have the durability we have the redundancy and the way we create that durability is we have this concept of regions
you probably saw in andy's presentation of nine regions around the globe each region is made up of hardened data
centers and clusters of data centers that are connected by private fiber so when you upload an object into s3 or
move a file into s3 for lack of a better way to explain it multiple copies will be made and spread across the
availability zone and across multiple availability zones and some availability zones are actually made up of multiple
data centers which is why we don't call them data centers we call them availability zones so we're very very durable if you're a
little bit familiar with aws you know as a customer you choose a region number one number two you say okay i want to build
my app in this availability zone and then if you follow best practices you'll load balance between availability
zones like netflix does for example you don't need to make those choices with s3 you upload a file into
s3 it'll be spread around the az and protect it for you and we have trillions of objects it took
us six years to get to a trillion and we've almost doubled that in the in the past two years so again
back to my earlier point the data growth here is massive and the scale of s3 is is uh is is almost limitless
and we do we handle about 1.5 million transactions per second again a transaction is a put a get a
copy a delete so when you're looking at s3 and you're comparing the cost of let's say s3 to on-prem storage you
can't just look at your storage costs and maybe your replication costs between multiple data centers
you also got to look at that network stack right because there's a cost in this cost to io to
access the storage cost of network to access the storage we bundle all that together in s3 it is a service
so with s3 you have this concept of buckets you create a bucket and you put your objects or your files into that
bucket using bucket names and you can have unlimited amount of objects but only up to 100 buckets can be
created and if you think you need to create multiple buckets in order to create the scale that you need or
to departmentalize the spend there are many ways to do that dropbox is a big customer they have millions and millions
of customers they only have two buckets so you don't need to create multiple buckets in order to create partitioning
we also have an option called reduce redundancy storage which carries four nines of durability so we have customers that say you know
what i just don't need that much durability because of how i use my application so spotify is a great example of that if
you're not familiar with spotify it's mp3 as a service so you can listen to music and if you
know what if they lose a file they can replace that any number of ways so rrs is going to save you about 20
percent and basically all that is it's the exact same performance as s3 it's just fewer copies across fewer
availability zones so there's less durability for that application and that's fine for for spotify and for
many customers s3 can also be used as a static website
for as little as 100 you could run a static website for years on top of s3 it's an extremely
efficient way to use a website for static content and we constantly drive price out on s3
right s3 was the flagship product the first product ever launched by aws we've done 16 price reductions since launch last year
we cut prices by 25 at re invent and for my customers that
spend hundreds of thousands a month on top of s3 approached me and said the last time i woke up in the morning and my storage
vendor saved me 25 overnight without any negotiation without any expensive rfp processes was
never right we so and we're going to continue to do that in price is definitely on top of mine for
our customers and they're constantly doing tco of on-prem versus s3 and that can be really challenging it's hard to compare
on-prem to s3 so customers will come to me and say look i i look at a petabyte of storage raw that
i buy from my storage vendor and it cost me x and i look at
s3 and s3 is more expensive than buying a petabyte of raw storage from my storage vendor my
traditional storage vendor but if you think about storage when you buy it the first thing you have to do is
raid protect it and so you're going to lose 20 percent on overhead rate protection is a way to protect your storage against failures
so you only have 800 terabytes of usable for that one petabyte of raw that you bought
then you're going to allocate storage to your users if any of you are i.t you have departments that say i need storage i need storage
if i think i need a terabyte of storage i might ask for five see if i can get that i might not use it
all so there's allocated storage and then there's actually what was written storage which can be far less
than what you actually purchased i met with one financial services organization that was spending 20 million dollars a
quarter on new storage and when they we looked at their utilization from raw to written they were eight to twelve percent
utilized depending on the department you looked at so there can be a lot of waste and storage versus on s3
you're only paying for what you're buying it's 100 utilized it's fully durable and by the way what
you see on the left side of the screen you have to do that twice because you need to replicate that to a second site if you're really going to protect your
application so if you're if tco is something you're looking at if you're modeling out your
costs year-over-year it's very easy to model s3 because it's a simple price per gig
so if you're looking at your business and going what are my costs going to look at look like year two year three year four it's definitely a conversation you

if that's what you need s3 is a great solution for you very durable storage for backup is fantastic for for

s3 is close to super compute content delivery with cdn which is a

our customers about a demand for a lower priced tier that was extremely inexpensive
but there was no such thing as a trade-off on durability if i'm talking about my long-term archive it's obviously data that's important to me i
want to save it for a long time so i can't have a trade-off on durability but maybe i can trade off on
how fast i can access the data so we launch glacier a penny per gig per month
so if you look at s3 it starts off at about nine and a half cents so almost in order of magnitude cheaper that's 120
a terabyte year again this is fully durable fully redundant same eleven nines as s3 for that penny per gig per
month same eleven nines of durability here's the trade-off if you're going to use glacier it'll
take three to five hours for us to return that file to you and i'll talk about the different ways you can interact with glacier
okay so you want to be and you can retrieve up to five percent of your archive
for free but if you go over that there's going to be a cost so there's a difference between storage costs and retrieval costs with glacier
so again five percent drives the right behavior when we looked at iron mountain and
other off-site tape vendors that store tapes for customers in in off-site vaults
we found that the average customer access those vaults about two percent of the time if you're if you're going to push it
off-site to a vault you really don't want to be accessing it very often so we doubled that plus a percentage and
gave you five percent access to the data you can access more than that but there'll be a cost so i encourage

backups get access very frequently right you want to use s3 for backups and then restore and i'll explain how you
can use lifecycle policies to manage between what's on prem what's in s3 and what's in glacier
so glacier inexpensive long-term archiving right eliminate tape museums many customers actually maintain tape museums
backwards compatible drives that are no longer for sale i've had customers do restores and have to go to

set and forget if you need it bring it back if you need to bring it back and compute against it or transcode on it
you can bring it back into aws and re-monetize that that asset and very very durable
so after we launched glacier shortly after that we launched aws s3 glacier integration okay so that's policy-based archiving
service i apologize for using some code here but basically what what you can do now
is you can set a policy and what you can see circled here is we have a customer that has a 30-day policy for data in s3
after 30 days on day 31 the data automatically moves down into glacier where you can set another policy in this
case it's 365 days but that could be seven years or it could be no policy
keep it forever right you can also put a zero policy on s3 so as soon as you put the data into
s3 you're no longer charged s3 charges as soon as that put is made it we move it automatically to glacier and you're
paying a penny per gig why would you do that you'd want to do that because if in the
times when you decided i want to restore this data i'm probably going to restore it and use it in aws versus download it
to my pc or to my data center so if you're going to use it in s3 s3 glacier is a great integration because you can
just move it right back in so here's a typical archive recovery
process for let's say a media company right they have tapes off site and they decide you know i'm not sure if you guys
are familiar with carol burnett but recently it was a 50-year anniversary and they re-monetized those assets and what they
had to do was go to tape those tapes get on a truck they come into the data center they pop them into a drive
they don't have that drive they get on ebay and find that drive especially if that tape's been sitting off-site for
35-40 years okay if they're lucky seventy percent of the data will be restored
nasa recently lost about thirty percent of all the images of the initial moon missions
because they put it on tape they suck it off site and data got lost on the restore but let's say they find the drives they
spin them up they restore what they can they transcode it into the latest and greatest formats one for the wii one for
the xbox one for the android one for the iphone maybe they they push it out to disk or maybe they push it out to cdn
and then they get new business value from that data and that can take days weeks even months versus with
glacier the asset was sitting in glacier i pulled a restore job and a few hours later i had it available to me
pushed it through ec2 compute transcoded it into 15 different formats and then monetized
it so big advantage to glacier typically your archive is in a dusty dark vault you don't ever
want to touch it you certainly don't want to compute against it when i look at nasdaq and fincloud and what they launched i've noticed that
their customers are actually doing more data mining than they are doing storage
growth so they've moved their assets over there they're under compliance so they can't be modified in any way but they
can be copied and put into high performance compute and they can mine that data and the financial services industry is
constantly being crunched to do it better faster cheaper than the next guy and data mining is a way to figure out what are my customers buying what else
can i sell them what customers are happy well customers aren't happy right what trade data happened today that i can take advantage of so they're
constantly crunching on the data so it's a great advantage to have that archive next to supercompute for the
first time complete genomics is a great story of a customer that adopted glacier
so complete genomics has a process by which customers send them genome data on cds and they send them to
a service that we provide which is called import export so we get those cds and we import them into their s3 bucket
then they run a genomics job against that data and then they they get a result and they
push it back to dvd or cd and we ship that back to the customer and then they delete the core data that
they received so the customer technology improves constantly and customer says you know what i want
to run another job against that same genome and so okay resend me the disk
well that's an inflection point what if i want to move over to 23andme and use them instead of complete genomics they just came out
with a price change or i saw an ad for them on google because they're number one if you if you're searching on google
for for obvious reasons but um so maybe i'll use 23 and maybe i'll ship my data to them okay so that's attrition so what
complete genomics did when glacier came out they said all right you know what i can afford to keep this data now so what they do after they run the genome
job is they drop the core data into glacier and they've told their customers by the way don't archive a copy of your
data i've got a copy for you for free so i'm going to archive that for you as a service to you oh by the way if you ever want to run it running a new genome
sequence you don't have to call fedex you don't have to ship me a cd wait for it to be ingested and wait a week to get the data i can run it in
hours so they've got better customer loyalty better faster cheaper than the competition
less attrition so a great way to use the data and when we launched glacier we thought we're going to see cannibalization of
revenue moving from s3 to glacier but what we didn't see that what we learned is that customers were making a sophie's
choice with their data they were deleting data that they otherwise wanted to keep but couldn't afford to keep and now they're keeping it for a very long time
in glacier or plan to anyway so amazon s3 is great when you're looking for an hsm or what's
called hierarchical storage management right move the data to the appropriate tier based on how how much access you need to that data
right using lifecycle policies to move data back and forth automatically archive data from s3
obviously to or rrs to glacier and you can delete data from glacier by policy so if
you do have if you're under any type of obligations to save data for a certain period of time many people do follow those policies but
very few people go back and delete the data when the retention period is over and expired
because it's costly it takes time i've got a tape library that's spinning all the time
with new data that i'm backing up if i'm going to follow my retention policies i need to call tapes back from some

refresh the tapes recycle the tapes what have you that takes time costs money a lot of people just you
know we we set and forget and that actually can add risk to your business if the retention period
period has expired that you don't need to keep the data any longer you can set a policy and have it automatically delete for you
so our other storage offering is elastic block storage okay so block storage is just like if
you have a server and you directly attach storage to it so that if the server crashes the data persists right that's what ebs is for
the the reason i like to the way i like to think about ebs is it's only usable through ec2
so s3 you can use you can use s3 and use nothing else at aws where for many companies we're their origin
and then they use other services outside of aws or they download the data when they need it when you launch an instance of ec2 you
can use the ephemeral storage which is the storage inside the server or the virtual server if you will
which is fine if when the server turns off and that's the value of ec2 right turn it on turn it off when you don't need it
well when you turn the server off if your data was sitting on ephemeral storage it goes away so if you want the data to persist you
would attach a one terabyte up 10 gigs up to one terabyte drive of abs to your ec2 server
and if you turn that server off the data will persist and you can turn the server back on and reattach it
if you're following best practices you'll actually do snapshots from ebs to s3 to have the durability of s3 so even
though the max you can do on ebs today is one terabyte you can rate or connect multiple
instances together of ebs to create whatever drive size that you need
for a long time ebs the performance of vbs was it scaled up and scaled down depending
on noisy neighbors and other things and so if your application needed consistent performance we really couldn't provide that in ebs
so a lot of erp applications need consistent performance and predictable performance so last year we launched provisioned iops so you can
provision up to 4000 iops for your ebs instance and anything in between
in order to support what your application needs and that has just blossomed the number of use cases for production
applications that can move over 2 2 ec2 and s3 and ebs
so again you launch an instance of ec2 attach an instance of vbs to it
and if your instance fails or you turn your instance off you can fail over to another ec2 instance or you can light up
a new instance if you had turned it off reattach the ebs drive to it and your application's back up and running
and you can do multiple instances of ebs in order to meet whatever the need of the application is and ebs
snapshots are very important to do it's a best practice right ebs again is not configured like s3 s3 is very very durable
so anytime you're doing ebs depending on what your comfort level is you can do snapshots every minute every 15 minutes
every hour so you definitely want to look at doing snapshots with ebs if the data is important to you and important to
preserve and it's easy to do right you just it's it's simple just set snapshot and it'll move over to to
s3 and it'll persist there if for any reason your ebs instance fails your ec2 instance fails pull the snapshot over you're back in
business and here's a great example supercell is a gaming company that uses ebs at scale
they're an online gaming company gaming is very hard to predict right you don't know what game is going to hit
you never know what the great new thing is bit strips is another organization that recently launched and has gone absolutely viral and the same thing

and you can move your database if you own a license of oracle database or sap you can move that
over that license can run in ec2 and then you can attach ebs to it and you can run your own database

off-site backup so you can put the gateway in backup or dr mode and it will keep one copy of the

i talked about ebs and you do snapshots to s3 this is using the same snapshot technology to move data from on-prem
into s3 the value to you is that now if you do need to fail over
in dr mode you can move the data from s3 into ebs attach your application with an ec2 to

assets you provision in aws are only accessible from your network not accessible from anywhere
else so it's a great way to create a secure environment in aws so data mirroring is a way where you're
not necessarily moving the data to my s3 storage solution you're moving it into aws to do data crunching on it do

it's great for file shares so you can set the gateway up in file share mode which will create if you you set up the

great for small departments who are constantly coming to you saying i need another terabyte in the other terabyte
gateway in file share mode is a great way to manage the needs of that department and you're only paying for what they use
versus what they're asking to be provisioned maybe you have consultants or interns that come in for the summer and they
just need a temporary file share and you don't want to put them on your expensive nas a great way to use that for departmental
file shares or for temporary file shares and then we just recently announced a
virtual tape library version of the gateway so the gateway emulates a tape library so anything you're using that talks to

it's on the shelf but still reachable by the robotic arm virtually and then when it goes into glacier

very simple to use if you do if you are running backup applications today nobody has to learn
anything new just continue to back up as if you were going to tape except it's a virtual tape
all this for 125 dollars a month so very inexpensive

launched publicly with s3 so just because of the sheer timing
of when we were founded cloud wasn't really an option for us to even look at when we started looking at our infrastructure
and architecture the other the other aspect of our business that really
made cloud not an option was the fact that digital hadn't really proliferated our world yet
you could maybe take a picture on a mobile phone no video and tablets themselves were
still on the drawing board so really all that we had were well the camcorders where you had sd cards or usb

to manage or to convert those assets into something that you could view online
take that vhs tape make a digital video of it and then allow you to watch it online
we had a lot of physical equipment that we had to bring in-house that we had to keep on premise to make that happen
for every vhs tape we had to have a deck that would play it for every film reel we had to have a
projector that would play it and then the photo and slide scanners to scan those
or the the physical slides and photos so our infrastructure grew naturally around that physical
equipment that we had in-house we had servers to capture those digital images as they came off of the the deck
or off of the film rail we had storage to store those resulting files
that we could then deliver online or use to produce a dvd
so as we grew over the seven years we we started to see some issues with
our infrastructure because as the business grew we added more physical equipment
which meant more files digital files which meant more physical servers both for processing the the assets that
were coming in as well as for storing the resulting digital video our reliability was not really as high
as we wanted we were running risks of downtime due to any type of a hardware failure
that meant a less than ideal customer experience and a less than ideal operations
experience we had to triple our full-time resources to manage that growing infrastructure
we had to add more network we had to add more power and to the best extent that we could we
had to add more space our costs were were highly variable
so the the static less frequently accessed files the what we call a source archive the
original digital copy of the converted tape or photo
or film were a lot higher than our costs were for the things that we were
delivering more frequently the videos that you were watching online the photos that you were looking at online
so what we started to realize was that our rate of growth was driving the need for our
infrastructure elasticity we had to be able to expand we had to be able to expand
quickly and we had to be able to do it in a manageable way so the numbers that i have on the screen
are related to our storage because this is uh drives where we went with glacier when
we started we had about eight tb of storage on premise 2011 that was around three
quarters of a petabyte and then sometime late last year we hit about one and a half petabytes of
on-premise storage very unmanageable so we started looking
at what our options were we knew we needed to solve this problem we could not
continue to add capacity on premise and keep costs under control so
we went through a little bit of a process and determining what we were going to do
we looked at what our needs were our use case and what our storage requirements so our
